content: p1 row 15 p1 k1 * yo k5 yo k2 s2kp k2 * repeat from * to * 14 times k1 p1 row 16 - p1 k1 p all sts until last 2 sts k1 p1 row 17 p1 k1 * yo k7 yo k1 s2kp k1 * repeat from * to * 14 times k1 p1 row 18 - p1 k1 p all sts until last 2 sts k1 p1 row 19 p1 k1 * yo k9 yo s2kp * repeat from * to * 14 times k1 p1 row 20 - p1 k1 p all sts until last 2 sts k1 p1 3  on the second repeat of the pattern end with row 10  now you should be about to start a rs row complete row as follows p1 k1 p all sts until last 2 sts k1 p1  now repeat the next 2 row until piece measures approx 40cm from cast on edge or the length desired when stretched slightly ws row p1 k1 p1 k1 p all sts until last 4 sts k1 p1 k1 p1 rs row - p1 k1 p1 k all sts until last 3 sts p1 k1 p1  place all sts onto spare needle cable or scrap yarn  now cast on again for the second side and repeat so that you have an exact or almost copy of your first side casting off  there are 3 different ways that i m going to explain how to cast off pick which suits your skill level and patience  the 1st way is probably the simplest cast off all sts loosely with a larger needle from both sides pin the cast off edges together from sides towards the centre leaving a section in the middle as your neck hole try it on the see how big you want the neckline the sample has a 68cm hole for the neck now hand sew the two sides together making sure that your right sides are facing  the 2nd way is shown on the sample on one side k60 cast off 52sts and then slip remaining 60 sts onto right needle if you would like a wider or narrower neckline adjust the st count accordingly on the other side k60 cast off 52sts and then slip the knitted sts from the right needle back onto the left needle now use the 3 needle bind off method to cast off both sleeves separately  the 3rd way takes a while but looks the nicest do the same as for the 2nd method but instead of the 3 needle bind off graft the sts together with the kitchener stitch method 4 blocking and finishing  now it s time to block the blocking process is what will keep your lace stretched out so you can see the beautiful pattern to block your garment soak in room temp water very gently squeezing so that all the air bubbles come out  pop the
